channel.title: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)
channel.description:
So this is an old computer, i got it in 2003, this was the first new computer i got, ( i know its not good). And this is the only Desktop i have, i rarely find it useful, since i mostly use my Laptop, so this summer i want to use my Desktop, but the problem is its too slow...i reformatted it and still slow, i don't know if i should build a new comp or upgrade this one, i mean its Dvd driver is only few months old expect for that all of its are old and the case is fine.
So i am not so sure what to do, i want to keep cost minimal, but have a computer that can support windows 7 and Debian as dual boot. I have limited knowledge with computer hardware so please help..attached is the specification of the computer, i wouldn't mind replacing everything (expect case, cause its fine i think, and DVD drive since its pretty much new).
My goal at least 100gb+ hard rive and at least , and 2gb+ram (even 1gb is ok i guess), manily used for programming, youtube surfing, email, word processing and definitely [b]not gaming[/b] . thanks you in advance. [IMG]http://i54.tinypic.com/2qn6wjo.png[/img]

item.title: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Well, they age in the sense that software becomes more demanding. Even if that seems to have slowed down in recent years due to casual computing being taken to other devices.

Read full topic

item.description:

mwiebelhaus:

But still 4 years is a pretty good life of a laptop and by that time the hardware is outdated and useless.

The battery maybe, but its not like CPUs age

item.title: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Ive had my dell E1505 since 2007 and its the only laptop ive ever ownded. Still going strong except I gave it to my sister who treats everything like shit and it its fucked now but I should be able to fix it, I think its a software thing but she lives 1000 miles away so idk for another month. But still 4 years is a pretty good life of a laptop and by that time the hardware is outdated and useless.

Read full topic

item.title: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)
item.dc:creator: @Teh_Dew1 Teh_Dew
item.description:
@Teh_Dew1 wrote:

I say just buy a new one. My HP that I bought back in 2008, kicked the bucket a few months ago and I decided to put new parts into it… I wasted $400, when I could of just saved the good working parts and built a better computer with that $400.

Read full topic
item.source: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)

item.title: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Then its just a case of who makes the least mistakes, ie the most reliable, which is who I try to go with. Providing performance is also decent.

Read full topic
item.source: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)

item.title: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:20, topic:399841”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=496956.msg3672337#msg3672337 date=1311019538]

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=496956.msg3671958#msg3671958 date=1310992518]

Incidentally this thread is so full of bias it isnt even funny. It’s just like the HDD-discussion, if you listen to people here you won’t be able to get ANY PC at all.

Can’t really speak without bias as everyone speaks from experience, which is their own personal bias. I can’t see how no bias is better as no bias means purely going off specs which we all know is a terrible idea. Build quality matters. Even when building your own the parts you buy need to come from somewhere with a decent reputation and decent warranty. Otherwise you risk compromising the whole machine. Obviously you can never be certain and for that reason bias sucks. Blame the capitalist world we live in :rolleyes:
[/quote]Listening to the people whining in this thread is a horrible idea though. Look at objective reviews for more accurate info, no single brand is bad, they all have pcs that arent good.

What do you mean by ‘objective reviews’? I think I’m being objective saying that I don’t like Western Digital hard drives, I don’t have anything against Western Digital, I don’t own stock in any other hard drive companies, I’ve just personally had about 8 bad Western Digital hard drives throughout the years, compared to 1 bad Maxtor and 1 bad Seagate. Other people have had other experiences, it doesn’t make any of them more objective than the other ones.
[/quote]And i’ve had 0 bad Western Digitals and 4 Maxtors. You see, this type of arguing doesn’t work because if he listened to everyone he wouldn’t be able to get a harddrive (or in this case, a brand pc).[/quote]
It’s not arguing, they are both objective reviews, though they conflict. Obviously this would lead someone to realize that all manufacturers make some number of bad drives.

Read full topic

I think I’m being objective saying that I don’t like Western Digital hard drives, I don’t have anything against Western Digital, I don’t own stock in any other hard drive companies, I’ve just personally had about 8 bad Western Digital hard drives throughout the years, compared to 1 bad Maxtor and 1 bad Seagate. Other people have had other experiences, it doesn’t make any of them more objective than the other ones.[/quote]And i’ve had 0 bad Western Digitals and 4 Maxtors. You see, this type of arguing doesn’t work because if he listened to everyone he wouldn’t be able to get a harddrive (or in this case, a brand pc).

item.title: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Tbh, if you’re going to run Windows 7, I’d recommend getting 4gb ram over 2. RAM is so cheap unless you go for ridiculously fast stuff, and at only 2gb I find myself swapping constantly even when not gaming.

Read full topic
item.source: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)

item.title: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Batteries are cheap. Like they give a fuck about a battery. Replacing an entire laptop is a different thing all together though. Also depends where you are, I am specifically talking about HP in the UK.

I agree Speljohan but like I said, no review is without bias. You either listen to other’s or you don’t. I can write a review and call it objective but here we are on the internet you have no idea what my motives for writing that review were, who paid me, what experience i have with other manufacturers etc etc.

Statistics could show you the brand with least risk involved but statistics are just statistics and individual cases can be completely different. That’s not to say people shouldn’t ask for others opinions though, everything you ever do is because people taught you or you learned to do it that way. Doesn’t mean it’s the best, just means that’s your way

For example I usually read Tomshardware and engadget for reviews but I’d be foolish to say their isn’t bias. Despite them both being pretty good at benchmarking and reviewing products.

Read full topic
item.source: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)

item.title: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)
item.dc:creator: @teh_spede Teh Spede
item.description:
@teh_spede wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:9, topic:399841”]Incidentally HPs are notorious for going wrong, but they just have really good business support. If you’re not a business you’re fucked.[/quote]Im not a business and my laptop’s battery died. I called them and literally in minutes my problem was solved by them sending a new battery that arrived the next morning.

item.title: PC Dilemma (New one or Old One)
item.dc:creator: @Scape-JAVA Scape-JAVA
item.description:
@Scape-JAVA wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:5, topic:399841”][quote author=`SJ_ link=topic=496956.msg3645351#msg3645351 date=1309329924]

I would try to stay away from Acers and Dells.

Words from the wise, stay away. I’ve have nothing but problems with my Acer, and my Dell computer. I personally over any manufacturer prefer HP.
[/quote]

I still have (and it still works fine) my first computer ever, an Acer, with an Intel 486 CPU, 4mb of RAM, and a 502mb hard drive.

Still, building a computer is by far your best choice. :)[/quote]

This, building is always best.

Might I suggest: http://www.tigerdirect.com/applications/SearchTools/item-details.asp?EdpNo=722908&CatId=7243#

for a decent motherboard.

I would try to stay away from Acers and Dells.

You could build a computer for a fairly cheap price (cheaper than buying a new computer). I would recommend looking on www.newegg.com
http://www.mysuperpc.com/

Or you can look on here.
bestbuy.
